items.title: Canada pledges $2.5B to Ukraine ahead of Trump talks
items.description:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney announced Saturday that Canada will provide an additional $2.5 billion in economic aid to Ukraine, a commitment designed to help Kyiv unlock crucial financing from the International Monetary Fund as peace negotiations between Ukraine and Russia enter a critical phase.

The announcement came during a meeting between Carney and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Halifax, Nova Scotia, ahead of Zelenskyy's scheduled talks with U.S. President Donald Trump on Sunday at Mar-a-Lago in Florida[1][2][3][4][5].

"The assistance will help Ukraine unlock financing from the International Monetary Fund," Carney said during the appearance with Zelenskyy, who also spoke briefly to reporters[1][2][3].

items.title: Scientists depart for month-long Antarctic glacier study

featured_image.name: Journey to the Melting Continent - The New York Times

items.description:
A vessel carrying nearly 40 scientists from four continents departed from New Zealand on Saturday, embarking on a month-long expedition to investigate Antarctica's most rapidly retreating glaciers and their accelerating contribution to global sea level rise[1][2].

The research team, which includes a reporter and photographer from The New York Times, will navigate the southern oceans to study the ice margins of West Antarctica, with a particular focus on Thwaites Glacier—a massive formation roughly the size of Florida that scientists have dubbed the "Doomsday Glacier"[1][2][3].

items.title: Russian drones, missiles pound Ukraine ahead of Zelenskyy-Trump meeting
items.description: Russia has attacked Ukraine with hundreds of missiles and drones ahead of what President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said would be a crucial meeting with Donald Trump to work out a deal to end nearly four years of war.

items.title: NASA to launch Pandora satellite to search for alien life

featured_image.name: NASA picks SpaceX to launch Pandora exoplanet mission | Space

items.description:
NASA and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory are preparing to launch the Pandora Mission in early January, a compact satellite designed to probe distant planets for signs of life by analyzing their atmospheric composition. The spacecraft bus was completed in January 2025, with the mission now targeting a January 5, 2026 launch from Vandenberg Space Force Base in California aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, according to the mission's principal investigator[1].

The $20 million mission represents NASA's latest effort to identify potentially habitable worlds beyond our solar system, focusing on detecting water vapor and other biosignatures in the atmospheres of at least 20 known exoplanets[1][2]. Funded under NASA's Astrophysics Pioneers program, which emphasizes small, ambitious missions with tight budget constraints, Pandora aims to complement observations from the James Webb Space Telescope by addressing a persistent challenge in exoplanet research: separating the light signatures of planets from those of their host stars[1][3].

items.title: Russian strike cuts power, heat to hundreds of thousands in Kyiv

featured_image.name: Half of Ukraine's capital in the dark after Russian strikes, ministry says

items.description:
A prolonged Russian assault on Kyiv early Saturday left more than 320,000 households without power and cut heating to nearly one-third of Ukraine's capital, as Moscow launched a massive barrage of missiles and drones targeting the city's energy infrastructure[1][2].

The attack, which lasted over nine hours beginning around 1 a.m. local time, killed one woman in the Kyiv region and injured at least 19 people in the capital, according to city officials[3][2][4]. The assault damaged residential buildings across seven districts and sparked multiple fires, forcing emergency evacuations from a university dormitory and a nursing home[5][2].

Kyiv Mayor Vitali Klitschko reported that approximately one-third of the city's more than 3 million residents lost heat as temperatures hovered near freezing[6][3][7]. "Almost a third of the capital is now without heat supply. There is no electricity in some areas of the left bank," Klitschko stated on Telegram[7]. DTEK, Ukraine's largest private energy company, implemented emergency power cuts across Kyiv and surrounding regions following instructions from national grid operator Ukrenergo[1][8].

items.title: Russian forces launch major assault on Kyiv

featured_image.name: 6 dead as Russian missiles 'rain down' in Kyiv, Ukrainian officials say

items.description:
The Ukrainian capital came under a large-scale Russian assault in the early hours of Saturday, December 27, with air defense systems engaged across the city and powerful explosions echoing through residential areas[1][2][3].

"Explosions in the capital. Air defense forces are operating. Stay in shelters!" Kyiv Mayor Vitali Klitschko wrote on Telegram[2][4][5]. Ukraine's air force announced a countrywide air alert as military officials warned of both cruise and ballistic missiles targeting the capital[1][3][6].

Reuters reporters in Kyiv witnessed air defense systems actively operating throughout the city[1][3][7]. A military Telegram channel confirmed the deployment of both cruise and ballistic missiles in the attack[1][6].

items.title: Australians are drinking less alcohol — except for one age group
items.description: Health-conscious Australians may be thinking twice about having that first or second beer, but not all of us are getting the message when it comes to alcohol and risky drinking.

items.title: U.S. researchers identify Russian missile site in Belarus

featured_image.name: Russia likely placing new hypersonic missiles at former ...

items.description:
U.S. researchers have identified the likely location where Russia is stationing nuclear-capable hypersonic missiles in Belarus, a deployment that underscores Moscow's growing reliance on nuclear threats as tensions with NATO escalate.

Jeffrey Lewis of the Middlebury Institute of International Studies and Decker Eveleth of the CNA Corporation said Thursday they are 90% certain the Oreshnik missiles are being placed at a former airbase near Krichev, about 190 miles east of Minsk and just three miles from the Russian border[1][2][3]. The researchers based their findings on satellite imagery from Planet Labs showing hurried construction that began in August[2][3].

"One dead giveaway in a November 19 photo is a military-grade rail transfer point enclosed by a security fence to which missiles, their mobile launchers and other components could be delivered by train," Eveleth said[2]. The imagery also revealed a concrete pad at the end of the runway that was covered with earth, consistent with a camouflaged launch point[2][3].

items.title: Interstellar comet's unusual tail prompts rethink of comet physics

featured_image.name: The latest images of insterstellar comet 3I/ATLAS

items.description:
The interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS, which made its closest approach to Earth on December 19, continues to challenge scientists' understanding of comet physics as it departs the solar system[1][2][3]. The object displays an unusual "anti-tail" pointing toward the Sun and containing particles far larger than typical cometary dust, behaviors that have prompted researchers to reexamine existing models of how comets form and evolve[4][2][5].

Astronomers using the Two-meter Twin Telescope at Teide Observatory in Tenerife detected wobbling jets within the anti-tail during an intensive 37-night observation campaign between July and September 2025[1][6]. This periodic motion allowed researchers to calculate that 3I/ATLAS's nucleus rotates once every 14 to 17 hours, marking the first time scientists have directly measured the rotation period of an interstellar comet from its surface activity[1][6].

items.title: Gold and silver hit all-time highs amid geopolitical tensions

featured_image.name: Gold and silver prices soar to new record highs - CNBC

items.description:
Gold and silver surged to all-time highs on Friday, extending a historic year-end rally for precious metals, while U.S. stock markets remained mostly unchanged in light trading following the Christmas holiday[1][2][3][4].

Silver jumped as much as 6% to reach a peak of $76.46 per ounce, marking a 164% gain for the year[4]. Gold rose 1.2% to a record $4,549.71 per ounce[4][5], while platinum hit an all-time high of $2,454.12[4]. The surge came as the S&P 500, Dow Jones Industrial Average, and Nasdaq Composite each fell less than 0.1% to close at 6,929.94, 48,710.97, and 23,593.10, respectively[6][7].

items.title: Trump and Zelensky to meet Sunday on Ukraine peace framework

featured_image.name: Zelenskyy says he and Trump have agreed to meet "in the near future"

items.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky confirmed Friday he will meet with President Donald Trump on Sunday at Mar-a-Lago in Florida to discuss a 20-point peace framework aimed at ending Russia's nearly four-year war in Ukraine, signaling what both sides describe as progress toward a potential agreement[1][2][3][4][5].

The high-stakes meeting comes as diplomatic efforts intensify, with Zelensky stating the plan is "about 90% ready" and expressing hope that "a lot can be decided before the New Year"[4][6][7]. The announcement follows what Zelensky described as a "very good conversation" on Christmas Day with Trump's special envoy Steve Witkoff and his son-in-law Jared Kushner, during which they discussed "new ideas" for bringing the conflict to a close[1][8][9][10].

items.title: Webb telescope detects most distant supernova ever seen

featured_image.name: Newly Detected Supernova Exploded When the Universe Was Just ...

items.description:
Four years after its Christmas Day launch, the James Webb Space Telescope continues to reshape astronomy, with scientists this month announcing the detection of the most distant supernova ever observed—a massive stellar explosion from when the universe was only 730 million years old.

The discovery, published in early December in Astronomy & Astrophysics, marks a significant milestone as JWST reaches its fourth anniversary. Launched on December 25, 2021, the $10 billion telescope has proven capable of observing nearly 98% of the way back to the Big Bang[1][2][3].

items.title: Inside the grooming process that made Epstein and Maxwell so dangerous
items.description: The arts camp was prestigious, and "Jane" had travelled almost 2,500 kilometres to attend. As she sat by herself on a bench between classes, a man and a woman approached her.
